HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 8, 1924

"PLEASE"
When the air blows soft, and tender shoots of green grass peek
from sullen hiding places, Dame Nature proclaims the year's at
Spring. The tang of the balmy season gets into our blood and perforce we surrender ourselves to its non-curable disease—Spring
Fever. Many of us, conquered completely by its distinguishing symptom, laziness, forget the plea of our ever-thoughtful leaders, cease to
think, and abide by "straight line" theories which we learned long
ago in high school days. We persist in taking the "shortest distance
between two points" regardless of its effect upon the grass.
Of late the university lawns have borne more pedestrian traffic
than the cement walks. As a consequence, unsightly paths have
put in their appearance on the campus, notably from the C. E. Hall,
around the end of the tennis courts to Gilman Hall, between the engineering buildings, and across the upper quadrangle in the direction of the Dormitory. Some thoughtless persons have even taken
the liberty to establish a "short-cut" from the top on the Bowl to
Charles Street. What a pity such persons are so near-sighted they
cannot see the driveway!
Hopkins grounds can compare in beauty with those of any college, large or small. Sigma Chi Beta may place "PLEASE" signs
and the Student Council may adopt the slogan "make for a pathless
campus," but only conscious effort on the part of every student in
the university to keep off the grass will give it a chance to get
started. Let us, then, try to curb the most common of human ailments—laziness, and make it an unpardonable sin to cut across the
campus.
A SPRING CHEERING SECTION
One of the greatest joys which can come to a college newspaper
is a letter of criticism, condemning either the paper itself or some
phase of college activity. Offhand, this may seem illogical reasoning, bringing before the public faults which might easily remain
concealed. However, censure and investigation stir up thought.
'When thought is aroused, some form of expression is necessary and
great things are often accomplished. For this reason, it would give
us great pleasure to receive a letter from an Alumnus asking "Where
is your cheering section ?"
Last Saturday the spring game schedule opened auspiciously;
the Baltimore public was on hand in unexpected numbers, a large
percentage of the undergraduate body was on the side-lines, the
band furnished welcome and diverting harmony, and the lacrosse
team displayed gratifying form for such an early date. But, there
was no cheering section.
In previous editorials we have endeavored to indicate the effect
of cheering upon the public and upon the players. We shall not
omit these considerations and merely repeat: "The teams need and
deserve support. A school is only as strong as its spirit. Unorganized cheering is of no avail."
To date, as far as we are aware, no arrangements for a cheering
section have been made. The responsibility falls upon the shoulders
of the Athletic Association. Some action, either individual or collective, should be taken—at once.
Why not have yell practice at Assembly?

RIFLE TEAM NEARS END OF
SUCCESSFUL SEASON
The Johns Hopkins Rifle Team
will have its mettle tested only
four more times this season. But
in these last four matches, to be
shot this month, the Black and
Blue marksmen will buck some ot
the strongest teams in the country, by dint of hard work and excellent shooting in previous
matches. The big event of the
season will be their participation
in the intercollegiate meet at Annapolis, while an event of no little importance is the triangle
shoot between Hopkins, Georgetown, and George Washington, to
be shot at Washington. Only two
mail matches will be fired on the
home range.
The two outstanding victories
of the season were those matches
won from Syracuse University by
a score of 3632 to 3601, and from
Georgetown by a score of 1791
to 1785.
Although the team has won
only ten matches to thirteen lost,
Captain Paul pronounced the season much more successful than
last year's, because of the higher
class of teams with which the
matches were shot. Both Captain
Paul and Wilgis, captain of the
team, agree that this year's team
has done more efficient and skillful work.

R. Earl Parkes, '25, Art Director
of the Playshop. All members of
the university, undergraduates in
particular, are invited to attend.
As usual, tickets may be procured
at the Post Office.

announced by Dr. John B. Whitehead, dean of the School of Engineering.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 8, 1924

"PLEASE"
When the air blows soft, and tender shoots of green grass peek
from sullen hiding places, Dame Nature proclaims the year's at
Spring. The tang of the balmy season gets into our blood and perforce we surrender ourselves to its non-curable disease—Spring
Fever. Many of us, conquered completely by its distinguishing symptom, laziness, forget the plea of our ever-thoughtful leaders, cease to
think, and abide by "straight line" theories which we learned long
ago in high school days. We persist in taking the "shortest distance
between two points" regardless of its effect upon the grass.
Of late the university lawns have borne more pedestrian traffic
than the cement walks. As a consequence, unsightly paths have
put in their appearance on the campus, notably from the C. E. Hall,
around the end of the tennis courts to Gilman Hall, between the engineering buildings, and across the upper quadrangle in the direction of the Dormitory. Some thoughtless persons have even taken
the liberty to establish a "short-cut" from the top on the Bowl to
Charles Street. What a pity such persons are so near-sighted they
cannot see the driveway!
Hopkins grounds can compare in beauty with those of any college, large or small. Sigma Chi Beta may place "PLEASE" signs
and the Student Council may adopt the slogan "make for a pathless
campus," but only conscious effort on the part of every student in
the university to keep off the grass will give it a chance to get
started. Let us, then, try to curb the most common of human ailments—laziness, and make it an unpardonable sin to cut across the
campus.
A SPRING CHEERING SECTION
One of the greatest joys which can come to a college newspaper
is a letter of criticism, condemning either the paper itself or some
phase of college activity. Offhand, this may seem illogical reasoning, bringing before the public faults which might easily remain
concealed. However, censure and investigation stir up thought.
'When thought is aroused, some form of expression is necessary and
great things are often accomplished. For this reason, it would give
us great pleasure to receive a letter from an Alumnus asking "Where
is your cheering section ?"
Last Saturday the spring game schedule opened auspiciously;
the Baltimore public was on hand in unexpected numbers, a large
percentage of the undergraduate body was on the side-lines, the
band furnished welcome and diverting harmony, and the lacrosse
team displayed gratifying form for such an early date. But, there
was no cheering section.
In previous editorials we have endeavored to indicate the effect
of cheering upon the public and upon the players. We shall not
omit these considerations and merely repeat: "The teams need and
deserve support. A school is only as strong as its spirit. Unorganized cheering is of no avail."
To date, as far as we are aware, no arrangements for a cheering
section have been made. The responsibility falls upon the shoulders
of the Athletic Association. Some action, either individual or collective, should be taken—at once.
Why not have yell practice at Assembly?
